fluff.lore: Armored in gilded plate and armed with towering blades that shimmer like sunfire, the Golden Company Greatswords are the embodiment of mercenary might—an elite cadre of warriors trained for decisive violence and unstoppable momentum. When the Golden Company commits its Greatswords, it signals the final judgment: this battle will end in fire and steel. Whether storming breached walls or cutting through the heart of enemy formations, their presence breaks the foe's spirit before blade meets flesh.

Clad in gleaming armor etched with exiled pride and mounted on destriers trained for war from birth, the Lancers use their speed and heavy armaments to send opposing men fleeing. In battle, the Golden Company Lancers serve as the hammer, slamming into disrupted battle-lines or driving into flanks softened by arrow or infantry assault. When they ride, they ride to end the fight. No commander would over look the crushing impact this force can have on the battlefield.

These trained and battle hardened soldiers have fought in more battles then many of the men of Westeros, earning a heavy coin purse and a life of glory following the golden skull of Bittersteel. Under the direction and command of great captains and knights, these armsmen stand shoulder to shoulder, rallying their fellow man to stay in the fight, countering enemy blows in unison as one complete force on the battlefield.

More then 500 knights fill the ranks of the Golden Company. Many of them the second or third sons of Westerosi Lords, whom traveled across the Narrow Sea in search of glory and renown that could only be found on the battlefield. The Golden Company's knights are well equiped with full plate, riding atop horses in steel barding, make up the tip of the spear able to charge headfirst into enemy formations most would not dare approach.

The Golden Company armored pikemen form the unbreakable heart of the Golden Company's disciplined phalanx, these Pikemen are the anvil of the most renowned sellsword legion in Essos, pehaps even the whole world. Armored in well-forged mail and bearing broad shields marked with the golden skull, are trained to fight not as men, but as a wall—unyielding, unified, unbreakable. These pikemen bare the honor of carrying a golden skull, of a fallen Captain General, mounted atop a pike into battle.

Following their Lords and knights, many squires entered the service of the Golden Company. No longer treated as simple servants, these squires were placed within the Golden Company's ranks and now given a chance to make their marks and earn knighthood. Many of these squires take up the sword to fight along side their knights in battle. Aiding in driving the enemy off the field of battle, with the promise of wealth and glory drving their reason.

The Golden Company is well known for their motto, “Our word is good as gold.” When hired on to fight, they make sure to give every penny’s worth on the battlefield. Their Swordsmen have trained relentlessly, letting them find any weak spot in an enemy’s defenses, exploiting it. Meanwhile, they almost never flee the field, even when faced with seemingly insurmountable odds, making them a sound investment for anyone with the coffers to afford them.

The Golden Company, the Free Cities’ most reliable mercenary group, offers several types of troops for hire. One being their Crossbowmen. These sharp-eyed fighters never waste a shot, resolutely waiting until enemies have closed to within perfect range before unleashing their bolts. These bolts punch through enemy armor with ease, especially at closer ranges. Anyone looking to bolster their forces can get a bargain by hiring them.

back_text.text: *Your army may only contain 1 War Elephant for each Golden Company Infantry unit.*

fluff.lore: Even the best-trained soldier will likely have no idea what to do when a massive elephant bears down on their battle line. The brutish War Elephants of the Golden Company stomp their way into enemy lines, seemingly impervious to attack, while they use their massive feet and tusks to demolish foes. However, they are simple creatures and without a handler nearby, it’s possible they’ll stop acting entirely, unsure about what action they should be taking.

fluff.lore: Every battle-field commander needs a man to enforce his orders, even if the men he commands are experienced knights or even war scarred Lords. To do the job, a well trusted and loyal Company Sargent, who has spend years leading men within the Golden Company from ordering shield walls in pike formations to leading assualts on fortified positions, is placed with the knights to ensure his commander's will and battle plans.

Those who seek wealth and glory flock to the caravans of the Golden Company and seek to join it's ever growing ranks. Freedmen, Peasants, debtors and Pirates alike join the ranks of the Golden Company as Auxiliaries to guard encampments and supply trains all in search of coin or a pathway to climbing the ranks and becoming a Captain.
